She has raised sheep in her property for three years. She currently has 15 sheep and poultry. When the animals have matured enough she sells them to her costumers at the local market. She learned this trade from her mother that is to say she has thorough knowledge regarding it.

Rosa wishes to use the loan to buy balanced foods, grasses for her animals and to fix the pen. Because of this she is requesting a loan of 500 Nuevos Soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: To buy balance food

loans.name: Petrona Del Carmen

texts.es:
Petrona agricultora, casada su esposo comerciante, sus hijos le apoya en el campo. Planes es mejorar el camino hacia la finca. Inicio desde muy joven siendo la agricultura el medio de vida para obtener el sustento. Se le presenta la dificulta que la finca está situada en la aria cerca del volcán y le afecta algunas veces por lo cual ella requiere de protección de químicos. Inicio con el apoyo de su esposo y tiene planes futuro sembrar variedades resistente en la cosecha.
Con el préstamo comprara urea, completa, fertilizantes y foliar ser aplicada a la cosecha. Obteniendo mejor calidad y mayores utilidades.
texts.en:
Petrona is married and works as a farmer. Her husband is a merchant while her children assist her in the fields. She has plans to improve the road that leads to her farm. Petrona started farming as a young woman and still pursues this livelihood to support herself. She experiences difficulty since her farm is located within close proximity to a volcano, so there are times when she needs protection from the chemical fumes. Petrona started with the support her husband and has future plans to plant more resistant varieties after the harvest.

With this loan she will purchase urea, comprehensive fertilizers, and plant nutrients to apply on her crops. This will help her achieve better quality and greater yields.

loans.use: Purchase urea, fertilizers, and plant nutrients

loans.name: Carmela

texts.es:
La Sra. Carmela, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Los Proceres”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martin,  Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 53 años y es madre de 01 hijo, que aun depende de ella. 

Carmela, anteriormente se dedicaba a la venta ambulatoria de costalillos por las diferentes calles de la ciudad. Ahora, con mucho esfuerzo deseo de superación, se dedica a la venta de golosinas, donde todos los fines de semana, vende en un Centro Turistico – Villa San Gabriel. Lo inicio por ella misma y porque le gusta estar en contacto con la gente, así mismo generar sus propios ingresos y crecer como persona y mujer. Hoy en día se siente muy contenta y tranquila, con el trabajo y negocioque realiza. 
 
Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000.00 Nuevos Soles, comprará golosinas como: chocolates sublimes, cañonazo; chupetines, chicles y caramelos en diferentes sabores y marcas; así de esta satisfacer a sus clientes. 

Se siente muy feliz con lo que realiza, cree que vale el sacrificio para cumplir sus sueños y metas que tiene trazado en su vida. Así mismo agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por brindarle apoyo a ella y a  demás mujeres que quieren salir adelante.
texts.en:
Mrs. Carmela is a member of the Communal Bank 'Los Proceres' in the District of Tarapoto, Province and Department of San Martin. She is 53 years old, single and has one son who is her dependent.

Carmela used to sell bags throughout the streets of the city. With a lot of hard work and desire to progress she now sells sweets/snacks in the tourist center Villa San Gabriel on the weekends. She started this on her own because she likes to be in contact with people. It allows her to generate income and to grow as a human being and a woman. She is very satisfied and at ease with her work and the business she has.

She will buy sweets like chocolates, lollipops, gum, candies of different flavors and brands with the loan of 1.000 Nuevos Soles to better serve and satisfy her costumers.

 Mrs. Carmela is happy with what she is doing and believes that her hard work is valuable since it helps her to realize her dreams and goals in life. She appreciates the assistance given by 'Movimiento Manuela Ramos' to her and other women who wish to prosper.

loans.use: To buy sweets/snacks to increase her stock at hand

loans.name: Yolanda Esteher

texts.es:
La Sra. Yolanda, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Los Proceres”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martín, Departamento de San Martín . Es Casada, tiene 62 años y es madre de 01hijo.
Yolanda , es una mujer luchadora y emprendedora, que ante la necesidad de generar sus propios ingresos y  motivada por ella misma, emprendió su pequeño negocio de Venta de Cosméticos de la línea Oriflame, y ya lleva varios años ejerciendo este negocio, obteniendo muy buenos resultados desde un inicio. Su negocio se encuentra  ubicado en su misma casa, en un local muy bien acondicionado, donde ofrece y recibe a sus clientes. También sale a ofrecer sus productos a sus amistades, en lo que al mes tiene varios pedidos, que lo hacen mediante el catalogo de su línea. En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio y esta muy orgullosa de alcanzar poco a poco sus metas.
 Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000.00, comprará  mas productos de belleza, para tenerlos en stock como: colonias, perfumes, talcos, desodorantes y cremas para damas y caballeros, lápiz labiales y para contornos de ojos , polvos compactos,  y otros productos  mas, todo esto para mantener contenta a su clientela. 

Yolanda, se siente muy contenta de su negocio que brinda y agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos, por el apoyo a mujeres que quieren trabajar y salir adelante,  espera que sigan así siempre y ayuden a muchas familias y mujeres emprendedoras.
texts.en:
Yolanda is a member of the "Los Proceres" community bank which is located in Tarapoto district, in San Martín province, in San Martín department.  She is 62 years old, married, and has one child.

Yolanda is a hard-working and enterprising woman who, faced with the need to make her own income and through her own self motivation, set up her small business selling Oriflame-brand cosmetics.  She has been in her business for several years and it has done very well since the beginning.  Her business is located in a part of her home which is very well adapted for the purpose and here she greets her customers and sells them her products.  She also goes out to sell her products to her friends and every month she has several orders that they make through her catalog.  She is continuing in the same business and she is very proud to be gradually achieving her goals.

With this loan for 1,000 Peruvian soles, Yolanda will buy more beauty products to have in stock such as aftershave, perfume, talcum powder, deodorants, ladies' and men's creams, lip sticks, eye liners, powder compacts and other products that will keep her customers happy.  

Yolanda feels very happy with her business and she is grateful to Movimiento Manuela Ramos for the support they provide to women who want to work and get ahead in life.  She hopes that they will keep doing this and that they help many families and enterprising women.

loans.use: To buy beauty products

loans.name: Rosa Elena

texts.es:
Rosa tiene 56 años. Ella es divorciada y reside junto a sus hijos en el distrito de Olmos, una zona agrícola de bastante movimiento comercial que se encuentra situada en la provincia de Lambayeque, a más de una hora y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo. 

Rosa es muy trabajadora lo que es evidente porque ha trabajado desde que era una niña. Desde hace ocho años ella vende por catálogo productos de belleza por ejemplo colonias, perfumes, y maquillajes.  Ella visita a sus vecinos y amistades y les ofrece sus productos.  Cuando empezó su negocio, Rosa sólo contaba con muestras y tenía poco productos. En los últimos 10 meses, Rosa ha podido crecer su negocio un poco más porque ahora tiene una vitrina para mostrar sus productos. 

Rosa desea invertir su crédito en su negocio para adquirir más productos y poder incrementar su capital de trabajo. Para lograr su objetivo ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles. Rosa se siente muy contenta por la confianza que los prestatarios de Kiva y Edpyme Alternativa deposita en ella y por la ayuda que le brinda a mejorar su vida poco a poco.
texts.en:
Rosa is 56 years old.  She is divorced and lives with her children in Olmos district: an agricultural area with quite a lot of commercial activity which is located in Lambayeque province, more than one and a half hours from the city of Chiclayo.

Rosa is a very hard-working woman who has worked since she was a little girl.  For the past eight years she has been selling beauty products such as cologne, perfume and make-up through a catalog.  She visits her neighbors and friends and offers them her products for sale.  When she started her business, Rosa only had samples and few products.  Over the last 10 months, Rosa has been able to grow her business a little more because now she has a display cabinet for displaying her products.

Rosa would like to invest her loan in her business so that she can acquire more products and increase her working capital.  In order to achieve her goal she is requesting a loan for 1,000 Peruvian soles from Edpyme Alternativa.  Rosa feels very happy for the trust that Kiva lenders and Edpyme Alternativa are placing in her and for the help that they are providing her with so that she can gradually improve her life.

loans.use: To acquire more products

loans.name: Teodoro

texts.es: Teodoro desde hace un tiempo es comerciante, casado su esposa le apoya en la venta de los productos. Se le presento la dificulta de sufrir un accidente el cual ocasionó descuido en el negocio. Lo inicio con ahorros propios. En este ciclo de préstamo será invertido en la compra de materiales de construcción como: cemento, piedra, bloques, arena, camisa entre otros materiales. Para la construcción de pared que será de división de la casa. Agradece a la financiera para el desarrollo y mejor nivel de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Teodoro is married and has worked as a merchant for some time. His wife helps him by selling products. Teodoro has faced difficulty since suffering an accident that caused him to neglect his business. He started out using his own savings.

In this loan cycle, he will invest his funds in the purchase of construction materials such as cement, stone, blocks, sand, and other items. He plans to build a wall that will act as a divider in his house. Teodoro is grateful for the financing so that he can develop and improve his family’s standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase construction materials to put up a dividing wall in his house

loans.name: Rodrigo Antonio

texts.es:
Rodrigo trabaja como guardia de seguridad, tiene como proyecto la construcción total de su vivienda obteniéndole seguridad y protección. Inicio realizando mejorara que poco a poco ha ido remplazando las paredes de plycem por concreto. El préstamo que solicitad lo invertirá en la compra de materiales de construcción: cemento, hierro, arena, piedrín, camisa para construir un anexo a la pared y el repello de las paredes de la casa.
Agradece a la financiera por su apoyo al desarrollo y bienestar de su familia.
texts.en:
Rodrigo works as a security guard and has plans to complete the construction of his home so that it can provide security and protection. He started this project by gradually replacing the walls made of fiberboard with concrete.

The loan he is requesting will be invested in the purchase of construction materials such as cement, iron, sand, and gravel so that he can build an extension as well as plaster the walls of his house. He is grateful for the financial support so that he can provide for the development and welfare of his family.

loans.use: Build an extension & purchase supplies to plaster the walls of his house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Home improvements. To buy building supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Repair the walls of his home

loans.name: Salim

texts.en:
Salim D. is from Sabirabad. He is a 40-year-old man living with his family. Salim grew up in a family of farmers. He got married when he was very young and soon became the father of two sons and one daughter. In order to provide a better life for his family, Salim started his business of cattle breeding. He has been practicing cattle breeding for ten years. 

Now he earns about 400 AZN a month selling dairy and meat products in the local bazaar. This business is his main source of income. Salim is requesting this loan of 1500 AZN to buy three more cows, increasing his total number of cows to six. This is his first loan with AqroInvest and Kiva. The extra income from this loan will help improve his family's living conditions.

loans.use: To buy three cows

loans.name: Reina De La Paz (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Reina de la Paz está formado por 10 mujeres quienes viven en diferentes lugares de la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad es considerada una de las más bellas por su arquitectura, su cultura y tradiciones, su gente es amable y muy cordial como nuestra socias quienes trabajan día a día en sus labores para  sacar  adelante a sus familias y apoyar en la economía de sus hogares.

La Señorita. Mónica Marisol L. es socia del banco comunal Reina de la Paz, vive en  la parroquia  Santa Ana, se encuentra en su primer crédito que realiza en el banco comunal y  fue invitada por su hermana a formar parte del mismo. Tiene 18 años de edad, es soltera y vive  con sus hermanos con quienes comparte los gastos del hogar.  Nuestra socia  labora como empleada domestica hace 2 meses, trabaja de lunes a viernes desde las 8 de la mañana hasta las 2 de la tarde y el tiempo que tiene libre le ayuda a su papá en la cría de pollos. El dinero de su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de pollos para iniciar su negocio propio. Su meta es tener su casa propia.

La Señora. Inés Celina T. vive por el centro de la ciudad de Cuenca, tiene 24 años, es casada y tiene 3 hijos de 9, 7 y 4 años de edad, sus dos primeros hijos estudian en una escuelita de la ciudad. Su esposo labora como albañil, no tienen casa propia por lo que viven en una casa prestada por un familiar. 
Doña Inés Celina hace 3 meses comenzó a vender almuerzos, trabaja de lunes a viernes, prepara los alimentos en la mañana y vende todo hasta el medio día.
Este es su primer crédito que realiza en la fundación y fue invitada por una amiga a formar parte del banco comunal, el dinero de su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de víveres para la preparación de sus almuerzos. Su meta es  tener su casa propia.
texts.en:
The 'Reina de la Paz' community bank is made up of 10 women who live in different parts of the city of Cuenca.  This city is considered very beautiful because of its architecture, its culture and traditions, and its kind and friendly people like these ladies who work every day to get their families ahead in life and to support their households financially.

Mónica Marisol L. is a member of the 'Reina de la Paz' community bank.  She lives in Santa Ana parish and this is the first loan she has requested as a member of the bank.  She was invited to join by her sister who was already a member.  Mónica is 18 years old, single, and lives with her siblings, with whom she shares the household expenses.  Mónica has worked as a cleaner for 2 months.  She works from Monday to Friday, from 8.00am to 2.00pm and in her spare time she helps her dad raise chickens.  She will invest her loan money in buying chickens so that she can start her own business.  Her goal is to own her own home.

Inés Celina T. lives in Cuenca city center.  She is 24 years old, married, and has 3 children aged 9, 7 and 4.  Her two eldest children attend elementary school in the city.  Her husband works as a construction worker.  They don't own their own home but live in a house which they are borrowing from a family member.

Three months ago, Inés Celina started selling lunches.  She works from Monday to Friday.  She prepares the food in the mornings and sells her meals up until midday.  This is the first loan that she has had from our organization.  She was invited to become a member of the community bank by a friend.  She will invest her loan money in buying food products to prepare her lunches.  Her goal is to own her own home.

loans.use: To buy chickens and food products

loans.name: Betsy Teresa

texts.es:
En el sector Las Piedras de la parroquia Picoaza en la ciudad de Portoviejo conocida por su cultura tradicional, por la alegría de su gente  y sus fiestas de san Pedro y San pablo, se reúnen cada quince días las socias del banco comunal  Las Piedras.

La señora Betsy  es socia fundadora del Banco comunal, además es la presidenta del banco y le gusta por la ayuda que le brinda la fundación a ella y a  sus compañeras. Tiene 42 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene tres hijos de 19, 16 y 10 años de edad los mismos que  estudian en  escuela, colegio y Universidad. Su esposo es comerciante.

Tienen con su esposo un almacén donde venden repuestos automotrices, aceites, baterías entre otros en el centro de la ciudad de Portoviejo, allí junto a sus esposo trabajan todos los días desde las 8h30 hasta las 18h00 y los domingos desde las 9h00 hasta las 13h00, nos cuenta que es negocio muy rentable y que llevan con su negocio ya por dos años, los repuestos los van a comprar a Quito una vez al mes.

Este crédito es para comprar  baterías, aceites, repuestos automotrices entre otros. Sus sueños son comprar un carro.
texts.en:
Every two weeks, the members of the 'Las Piedras' community bank meet in Las Piedras neighborhood, in Picoaza parish, in the city of Portoviejo.  This city is known for its traditional culture, the cheerfulness of its people and the San Pedro and San Pablo fiestas. 

Betsy is a founding member of the community bank and she is also its president.  She likes being a member of the bank because of the help that Fundación Espoir provides to her and her fellow members.  Betsy is 42 years old, married, and has three children aged 19, 16 and 10.  Her children are attending elementary school, high school and university.  Her husband is a salesman.

Betsy and her husband have a store where they sell car parts, oil, batteries, and other products, in Portoviejo city center.  Together with her husband, Betsy works every day from 8.30am to 6.00pm.  On Sundays they work from 9.00am to 1.00pm.  She tells us that their business is very profitable and that they have been in the business for two years now.  They travel to Quito to buy spare parts once a month.

This loan will be used to buy batteries, oil, car parts and other products.  Betsy's dream is to buy a car.

loans.use: To buy car parts, oil, batteries, etc.

loans.name: Mónica Mercedes

texts.es:
En un sector conocido como Las Piedras de la parroquia Picoaza de la ciudad de Portoviejo conocida por su cultura tradicional por la alegría de su gente  y sus fiestas de san Pedro y San pablo, se reúnen cada quince días las socias del banco comunal  Las Piedras.

La señora Mónica  es socia fundadora del Banco comunal, además es la secretaria  del banco y le gusta porque a través de los créditos ella y sus compañeras han podido surgir en sus negocios y así pueden aportar con los gastos del hogar. Tiene 43años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos de 23, 22 y 14 años de edad, los  dos mayores estudian en Universidad y el menor en colegio. Su esposo trabaja en el Ministerio de Agricultura. Ella es orientadora en una escuela de la localidad.

Tienen una finca en el campo en la cual junto a su hijo mayor que estudia para médico veterinario han construido una granja en la cual empezaron un negocio de cría de cerdos, recién tienen este negocio seis meses, con un crédito anterior empezaron con la compra de unas chanchas las mismas que ya parieron y están en la cría de estos y otros cerdos que compraron pequeños, piensan vender los cerdos cuando estén grandes a comerciantes de la ciudad.  En este negocio su hijo que es el encargado trabaja todos los días ya que además  le sirve de práctica en sus estudios.

Este crédito es para comprar alimentos, medicinas y otros productos para el mejor crecimiento de estos animalitos. Sus sueños son comprase un carro.
texts.en:
Every two weeks, the members of the 'Las Piedras' community bank meet in Las Piedras neighborhood, in Picoaza parish, in the city of Portoviejo.  This city is known for its traditional culture, the cheerfulness of its people and the San Pedro and San Pablo fiestas.

Mónica is a founding member of the community bank and also its secretary.  She likes being a member of the bank because, through the loans, she and her fellow group members have been able to make progress in their businesses and help with their household expenses.  Mónica is 43 years old, married, and has three children aged 23, 22 and 14.  Her two eldest are studying at university and her youngest is in high school.  Her husband works for the Ministry of Agriculture.  Mónica is a counselor at a local school.

Mónica and her husband have a plot of land in the country where, together with their eldest son who is studying to be a vet, they have built a farm and started a business raising pigs.  They have had this business for six months.  They used a previous loan to start buying pigs.  These have already given birth and they are raising them and some other young pigs that they bought.  They are planning to sell the pigs when they are bigger to salespeople in the city.  Their son is in charge of the business and he works in it every day as it provides him with practice for his studies.

This loan will be used to buy feed, medicines and other products needed to better raise their animals.  Their dream is to buy a car.

loans.use: To buy feed, medicines and other products to help grow their pigs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy creams, perfume, cosmetics, costume jewelry, etc.

loans.name: María Fernanda

texts.es:
En un sector conocido como Las Piedras de la parroquia Picoaza de la ciudad de Portoviejo conocida por su cultura tradicional por la alegría de su gente  y sus fiestas de san Pedro y San pablo, se reúnen cada quince días las socias del banco comunal  Las Piedras.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora María, tiene 23 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre,  tiene una niña de 4 años y tres meses la cual es su adoración. El marido es chofer en una empresa de agua. Ella estudia a distancia en la Universidad de Guayaquil los sabados y domingos.

Tiene un almacén en el que se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo y accesorios de la marca Belessa. Trabaja todos los días desde las 8h30  hasta las 18h00, nos cuenta que  tiene su almacén hace dos años pero antes de eso se dedicaba  a la venta puerta a puerta pero poco a poco fue ahorrando hasta poner su local. Su mercadería  la va a comprar a Huaquillas, Guayaquil y Ambato una o dos veces al  mes de acuerdo a lo que necesite.

Este crédito es para comprar pantalones, camisetas, blusas, ropa de niños, interiores, entre otras prendas. Está en el Banco Comunal desde hace 4 ciclos y  le gusta por la ayuda y por las charlas educativas. Sus sueños son seguir creciendo en su negocio.
texts.en:
Every two weeks, the members of the 'Las Piedras' community bank meet in Las Piedras neighborhood, in Picoaza parish, in the city of Portoviejo.  This city is known for its traditional culture, the cheerfulness of its people and the San Pedro and San Pablo fiestas.

Here we meet María.  María is 23 years old and lives with her partner.  She has a daughter who is 4 years and 3 months old and is her little treasure.  María's husband is a driver for a water company and María studies at Guayaquil University on Saturdays and Sundays.

María has a store in which she sells all kinds of clothes and Belessa-brand accessories.  She works every day from 8.30am to 6.00pm.  She tells us that she has had her store for two years and before that she sold her products door to door.  She gradually saved up until she was able to set up her sales location.  She buys her merchandise in Huaquillas, Guayaquil and Ambato once or twice a month, according to what she needs.

María will use this loan to buy pants, t-shirts, blouses, children's clothes, underwear and other clothes.  She has been a member of her community bank for four loan cycles and she likes being a member because of the help she receives and also the educational talks.  Her dream is to continue growing in her business.

loans.use: To buy pants, t-shirts, blouses, children's clothes, underwear, etc.

loans.name: Jessica Marisol

texts.es:
En un sector conocido como Las Piedras de la parroquia Picoaza de la ciudad de Portoviejo conocida por su cultura tradicional por la alegría de su gente  y sus fiestas de san Pedro y San pablo, se reúnen cada quince días las socias del banco comunal  Las Piedras.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora Jessica, tiene 35 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene seis hijos  de 18, 17, 10, 5, 1 año y un bebe de tres meses, la mayor esta en Universidad, otra en colegio y dos en escuela. El marido trabaja en una urbanización. Está en el Banco Comunal desde hace 3 ciclos y  le gusta porque con los créditos se ayuda en su negocio.

Se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo, su forma de  ventas es puerta a puerta y  también vende en su  casa hasta donde llegan sus clientes, nos cuenta que  le realizan muchos pedidos sus clientes.  Hay semanas que trabaja todos los días y en otras solo tres días de acuerdo a como estén las ventas, deja a crédito a sus clientes  y cobra cada quince días. Su mercadería  la va a comprar a  Guayaquil y cuando quiere de urgencia compra en Portoviejo también.

Este crédito es para comprar pantalones, camisetas, blusas, ropa de niños, interiores, entre otras prendas. Sus sueños son seguir adelante en su negocio y que este crezca cada dia mas.
texts.en:
Every two weeks the members of the Las Piedras community bank meet in Las Piedras neighborhood, in Picoaza parish, in the city of Portoviejo.  This city is known for its traditional culture, the cheerfulness of its people and the San Pedro and San Pablo fiestas.

Here we meet Jessica.  She is 35 years old, lives with her partner, and has six children aged 18, 17, 10, 5, 1 and 3 months.  Her eldest is at university, another is in high school and two are in elementary school.  Her husband works in a housing development.  Jessica has been a member of her community bank for 3 loan cycles and she likes being a member because the loans help her in her business.

Jessica's business is selling all kinds of clothes.  She makes her sales door to door and her customers also come to her home to buy.  She tells us that her customers make a lot of orders.  Some weeks she works every day and others she only works three days, depending on her sales.  She leaves her products with her customers on credit and collects payment every two weeks.  She buys her merchandise in Guayaquil but when she needs it urgently she also buys in Portoviejo.

Jessica will use this loan to buy pants, t-shirts, blouses, children's clothes, underwear and other garments.  Her dream is to continue in her business and for her business to continue growing every day.

loans.use: To buy pants, blouses, t-shirts, children's clothes, underwear, etc.

loans.name: Inés Elida

texts.es:
En un sector conocido como Las Piedras de la parroquia Picoaza de la ciudad de Portoviejo conocida por su cultura tradicional por la alegría de su gente  y sus fiestas de san Pedro y San pablo, se reúnen cada quince días las socias del banco comunal  Las Piedras.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Inés, ella tiene 29 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene tres hijos de 11, 9 y de 6 años de edad que estudian en colegio y escuela. Su esposo trabaja en el campo de la construcción.

Ella tiene una tienda de viveres de consumo, vende arroz, azúcar, aceites, detergentes, etc. en la cual trabaja todos los días desde las 6am hasta las 20h00 y a veces hasta más tarde,  los productos los compra en el centro de Portoviejo aunque la mayoría de sus productos los recibe en su local. También realiza el crédito para que su esposo trabaje ya que él se dedica alquilar encofrados de casas para lo cual necesita comprar tablas de madera, cañas entre otras cosas, nos cuenta la señora que a su esposo realiza hasta dos encofrados por semana y por eso necesita comprar más material para poder cumplir con sus obras.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, detergentes, embutidos y para comprar tablas, cañas etc. Está en el Banco Comunal hace 4 ciclos y le gusta porque con estos créditos su esposo empezó su negocio. Sus sueños son que no le falté trabajo a su esposo  y que su tienda crezca cada día más.
texts.en:
Every two weeks the members of the 'Las Piedras' community bank meet in Las Piedras neighborhood, in Picoaza parish, in the city of Portoviejo.  This city is known for its traditional culture, the cheerfulness of its people and the San Pedro and San Pablo fiestas.

Here we meet Inés.  She is 29 years old, married, and has three children aged 11, 9 and 6 who are studying in high school and elementary school.  Her husband works in construction.

Inés has a grocery store.  She sells rice, sugar, oil, detergents, etc.  She works in her store every day from 6.00am to 8.00pm and sometimes until even later.  She buys some of her products in the center of Portoviejo although most of them are sent directly to her premises.  Inés is also requesting this loan to help her husband in his work since he creates formwork for houses and needs to buy wooden planks, cane and other materials.  She tells us that her husband does up to two formwork jobs a week and, for this reason, he needs to buy more material so that he can carry out his work.

Inés will use this loan to stock her store with more merchandise.  She will buy rice, sugar, oil, detergents and sausages.  She will also buy planks, cane, etc. for her husband.  Inés has been a member of her community bank for four loan cycles and she likes being a member because through the loans her husband started his business.  Her dreams are for her husband to stay in work and for her store to keep growing every day.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, oil, detergents and sausages.  To buy planks and cane.

loans.name: Cruz María

texts.es:
En un sector conocido como Las Piedras de la parroquia Picoaza de la ciudad de Portoviejo conocida por su cultura tradicional por la alegría de su gente  y sus fiestas de san Pedro y San pablo, se reúnen cada quince días las socias del banco comunal  Las Piedras.

La señora Cruz María es socia fundadora del Banco comunal y le gusta por la seriedad tanto de sus compañeras como los de la institución. Tiene 52 años de edad, hace varios años su esposo falleció pero de esa relación tuvo seis  hijos los cuales ya son mayores de edad pero aun dos de ellos viven con ella, uno de ellos está comprometido y vive con su esposa y su hijo pequeño y la menor que está soltera.

Ella realiza el crédito para su hijo ya que es él quien se hace cargo de los gastos familiares,  su hijo se dedica al comercio, vende legumbres y mariscos, el recorre la ciudad en su carro. Además de esto en las tardes también se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo ya que como dice ella su hijo vende de todo con tal de ganarse el sustento diario y su forma de apoyarlo es realizar estos créditos y asistir a las reuniones, nos cuenta que lleva en estos negocios ya por siete años y que le va bien.

Este crédito es para comprar legumbres, mariscos y ropa de todo tipo. Sus sueños son tener una tienda en su casa para así poder contribuir más con los gastos del hogar.
texts.en:
Señora Cruz María is a founding member of the bank. She likes the responsible attitude of both the bank and the other members. She is 52 years old; her husband passed away several years ago. She has six children from her marriage, all of them now adults although two still live with her, one of whom is engaged and lives with his fiancee and their little son, and the youngest who is single.

Señora Cruz María is taking on this loan for her son as it is he who is responsible for the family’s expenses. He has a business selling vegetables and seafood which he takes to the town in his car. In addition in the afternoons he sells all types of clothing. According to his mother, her son sells anything and everything in order to earn a living. Her way of helping is to take on the loan and attend the bank meetings. Her son has had his business for seven years and all is going well.

The loan will be used to buy vegetables, seafood, and clothing. Her dream is to have a store in her house so she can contribute more to the cost of running the household.

loans.use: to buy vegetables, seafood, and clothing

loans.name: Yolanda Monserrate

texts.es:
En un sector conocido como Las Piedras de la parroquia Picoaza de la ciudad de Portoviejo conocida por su cultura tradicional por la alegría de su gente  y sus fiestas de san Pedro y San pablo, se reúnen cada quince días las socias del banco comunal  Las Piedras.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora Yolanda, tiene 30 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene un hijo de 4 años de edad. Su esposo es comerciante. Ella estudio y obtuvo el título de licenciada en la Universidad, en la actualidad trabaja como profesora por contrato en una escuela.

Se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo, su forma de  venta es puerta a puerta, también vende en su  casa hasta donde llegan sus clientes,  trabaja  tres días a la semana desde las 13h00 hasta las 17h00, en estos meses está de vacasiones pero cuando estaba dando clases vendía todos los días a sus amigas en la escuela, deja a crédito a sus clientes  y cobra cada quince días. Su mercadería  la va a comprar a  Guayaquil, lleva en esta actividad por dos años.

Este crédito es para comprar pantalones, camisetas, blusas, ropa de niños, interiores, entre otras prendas. Es socia fundadora del Banco comunal y le gusta por las charlas educativas. Sus sueños son tener un local donde vender sus productos.
texts.en:
Every two weeks the members of the community bank Las Piedras meet in the neighbourhood of Las Piedras located in the parish of Picoaza in the town of Portoviejo. The town is known for its traditional culture, for its happy people, and for its San Pedro and San Pablo celebrations. 

30-year old Yolanda is a member of the bank. She is married and has a 4-year old son. Her husband is a businessman. Yolanda has a university degree and currently works on contract in a school. She also sells all types of clothing from door to door as well as to customers who come to her house.  During the vacations she works at this job three days a week from 1pm to 5pm , but when she is teaching she sells to her friends at the school. She extends credit to her customers and collects from them every two weeks. She buys the merchandise from Guayaquil and has had her business for two years.

The loan will be used to buy pants, shirts, blouses, children’s clothing, underwear etc. Yolanda is a founding member of the bank and particularly enjoys the educational talks. Her dream is to have a stall where she can sell her products.

loans.use: to buy pants, shirts, blouses, children’s clothing, underwear etc

loans.name: Azucena Monserrate

texts.es:
En un sector conocido como Las Piedras de la parroquia Picoaza de la ciudad de Portoviejo conocida por su cultura tradicional por la alegría de su gente  y sus fiestas de san Pedro y San pablo, se reúnen cada quince días las socias del banco comunal  Las Piedras.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora Azucena, tiene 40 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene dos hijos de 11 y 7años los mismos que estudian en escuela. El marido es policía. Lleva en el Banco Comunal  ya por tres ciclos y  le gusta porque los créditos salen  rápido y sin tantos requisitos y papeleos.

Se dedica al comercio, vende productos de Yanbal (productos de belleza, perfumes, cosméticos y otros accesorios).  Además de esto también se dedica a la venta de sandalias y zapatos de todo tipo. Trabaja tres días a la semana de dos a tres horas por dia, lo que es sandalias y zapatos se los traen desde otras ciudades a precio para comerciantes, ella deja sus productos a crédito y cobra cada semana, nos cuenta que lleva en esta actividad ya por tres años y que le ha ido muy bien.

Este crédito es para comprar perfumes, cremas, cosméticos, sandalias y zapatos de temporada. Sus sueños son tener un taxi nuevo ya que tienen uno pero ya está un poco deteriorado.
texts.en:
Every two weeks the members of the community bank Las Piedras meet in the neighbourhood of Las Piedras located in the parish of Picoaza in the town of Portoviejo. The town is known for its traditional culture, for its happy people, and for its San Pedro and San Pablo celebrations. 

40-year old Señora Azucena is a member of the bank. She lives common-law with her husband and has two children aged 11 and 7 who attend school. Her husband is a policeman. 

Azucena has been with the bank for three loan cycles. She likes it because she can get a loan quickly and without too much paperwork. She sells Yangal beauty products such as perfumes, cosmetics, and accessories. In addition she sells all types of sandals and shoes.  Azucena works 2 to 3 hours a day three days a week. The footwear is brought in from other towns at dealer prices. She’s been doing this work for three years and is doing well.

The loan will be used to buy perfume, lotions, cosmetics, sandals and shoes appropriate for the season. Azucena’s dream is to have a new taxi as the one she has is somewhat dilapidated.

loans.use: to buy perfume, lotions, cosmetics, and footwear

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more clothing

loans.name: Pav

texts.en:
Pav S. is a 47-year-old farmer who lives in the province of Kompong Cham. Pav S. is married to Chea Kosal, age 48. This couple, who work together in the farming business, has five children: two are now married and three are single. One of their children is a sewing worker at the garment factory in Phnom Penh City. 

Pav S. used her land to plant rice crop and vegetables two months ago, but her crops are not growing well because they need more fertilizer. To remedy the situation, she would like a loan to buy two sacks of fertilizer and gasoline. With the rest of the funds she will pay for harvesting costs (renting a few laborers).

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline and to pay for harvesting costs

loans.name: Van

texts.en:
The woman in the photograph is Van T., age 45, who lives in the province of Kompong Cham, the best territory for farming. Van T. is a married woman who is devoted to her five single children. Two of her children are working at different occupations and sharing the responsibility for earning daily revenue with Van T.. 

Van T. owns a big farm that she inherited from her grandmother. She grows various crops on it. For additional income, Van T. wishes to plant a peanut crop, but she doesn’t have enough capital to do it yet. Therefore, Van T. would like to ask for a loan from Kiva to buy fertilizers and peanut seed for planting.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and peanut seed for planting

loans.name: Estrella's Group

texts.en:
Estrella B. is from the village of Minanga Sur. She is 61 years old and the group leader of an 8-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Estrella B.'s Group.

Estrella is married and has 4 adult-aged children. She owns and operates a business raising livestock, primarily pigs, for fattening and sale. Estrella has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2006, Estrella joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estrella has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Estrella is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the 9th loan taken out by Estrella from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase feed and other supplies

loans.name: Lerma's Group

texts.en:
Lerma G. is from the village of Minanga Sur. She is 39 years old and the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Lerma G.'s Group.

Lerma is married and has 2 school-aged children. She owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling clothing and shoes in the local community. Lerma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2006, Lerma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lerma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Lerma is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Lerma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to expand the business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to expand his business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To complete his shop

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy supplies for her business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To repair his taxi

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To improve his photography business

loans.name: Evariste

texts.en: Evariste sells different items.  He is 31 years old and engaged, with no children. Evariste has been selling different items for 13 years. His loan will be used to buy more items such as sugar, salt, matches and candles. He hopes to save the new profits from his business for the future.

loans.use: To buy sugar, salt, matches and candles to resell

loans.name: Velonique

texts.en: Velonique is 30 years old, and married to a mechanic. They have three children between three and eight years old. Velonique sells various items such as salt, cooking oil, and soap. She has been in this business for one year.She has requested this loan in order to add more items to her business.  She will use the profits to reinvest in her business for its continued growth.

loans.use: To buy salt, cooking oil and soap to resell

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba G. is a petty trader from Dompoase near Elmina, Cape Coast. For the past five years, she has been selling an assortment of products. She is mobile – she carries her goods from village to village. Aba is married to a farmer and they have five children. The income she earns is used to pay for their children’s school fees and for household expenses. 

With a loan, Aba hopes to grow her business and set up her own stall some day. The picture shows Aba on her normal rounds with a few clothes, Pampers and a bag.

loans.use: To grow her business and set up her own store some day

loans.name: Essumaba Adjoa

texts.en: Essumaba Adjoa B. has been a petty trader for several years, selling an assortment of items such as baby’s diapers, clothes and bags, in Dompoase near Elmina, Cape Coast. She carries her wares to neighboring villages, usually an hour’s walk or more, to sell. She and her husband, a farmer, have three children. Essumaba's income helps pay for their children’s education and for some of the household expenses. Essumaba hopes to develop her business and set up her own store one day. A loan will help her purchase a greater variety of items for sale. The extra profits will be reinvested in her business for further growth.

loans.use: to purchase a greater variety of clothes

loans.name: Mary Annan Ama

texts.en: Mary Annan Ama E. is married to a farmer and has 6 children. The family lives in Dompoase, near Elmina, Cape Coast. Mary Annan has been selling loaves of bread and other food products for six years. She walks to neighboring villages, usually an hour’s walk or more, balancing the basin (shown in the picture) on her head. Her earnings go towards her children’s school fees and some household expenses. Mary Annan hopes to develop her business and will use the loan to invest in more ingredients and food products to generate higher sales.

loans.use: to buy more ingredients and food products

loans.name: Beatrice Annan Ekua Atta

texts.en: Beatrice Annan Ekua Atta P. sells bread, doughnuts and other food products in Dompoase, near Elmina, Cape Coast. She plies her trade from village to village – these walks typically take at least an hour. Beatrice Annan and her husband, a farmer, have one child. Her earnings contribute to their child’s schooling and their home’s utility bills. Beatrice Annan’s goal is to develop her business and increase her profits so that she can set up her own store one day. A loan will allow her to purchase more ingredients to prepare more doughnuts and generate more sales.

loans.use: to purchase more ingredients

loans.name: Mary Ansah Ekua

texts.en: Mary Ansah Ekua G. sells corn in Dompoase, near Elmina, Cape Coast. Corn is typically used in the preparation of banku and kenkey, staples in the Ghanaian diet. Mary Ansah has been selling corn in both small and large quantities for ten years. She is married to a farmer and they have six children. Her income contributes to their children’s schooling and to their household expenses. With so many mouths to feed, Mary Ansah’s goal is to increase her income by developing her business. The loan will help her purchase more maize and also diversify to other food products.

loans.use: to purchase more maize and other food products

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose A. has been running a business cooking food in Dompoase, near Elmina, Cape Coast, for eight years. She sells rice with hardboiled eggs and stew. Rose is married to a farmer and they have three children. The income from her business helps pay for their children’s school fees and the family’s utilities bills. Rose aims to develop her business by increasing the amount and variety of food she sells. A loan will go towards purchasing more ingredients and the profits will be reinvested in the business.

loans.use: to purchase more ingredients

loans.name: Nana Ekua

texts.en: Nana Ekua F. has a shop selling provisions in Dompoase near Elmina, Cape Coast. Nana has attained a senior high school level of education. She is a single parent taking care of six dependants. It has been 10 years since she started this business. She pays her dependants' school fees and other bills. Her loan is going to serve as additional income to be able to buy extra provisions to sell. The additional profit will be used to build another shop in a different location.

loans.use: To buy extra provisions to sell

loans.name: Abena Maggi Margret

texts.en: Abena Maggi Margret A. is married and has 4 children. Her husband is a farmer. Abena Maggi sells provisions at Dompoase, near Elmina, Cape Coast. She helps her husband pay school fees and utility bills. Abena will add the loan to her capital to buy more provisions to sell. Her business objective is to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: to buy more provisions to sell

loans.name: Petronila

texts.en: Petronila has owned a business selling foodstuffs for 15 years. She is 48 years old, married and has six children aged between 10 and 25. Her husband works as a gardener. Petronila's loan will be used to buy more foodstuffs such as fresh dairy products, cakes, juice, and soda. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to set up a hair salon. Her dream is to see her children complete their further studies.

loans.use: to buy fresh milk, cakes, juices and soda

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: Rita W. sells a local dish called “piwa” (made of corn and served with cooked beans) in Dompoase, near Elmina in Cape Coast. She is divorced and lives with her 4 children. Rita has acquired senior high school education. She is able to provide for the family's basic needs with the income she makes from her sales. Her loan will be used to buy extra quantities of corn and beans. Her business goal is to build a small restaurant. In this picture, Rita is showing the cooked beans used to serve the "piwa".

loans.use: to buy extra quantities of corn and beans

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba A. prepares piwa (a local dish made from corn) at Dompoase near Elmina in Cape Coast.  This dish is typically served with cooked beans. She is married to a farmer and together they take care of their 6 dependents. She has not been in this trade for long. With her earnings, she assists her husband in paying school fees and utility bills. She will add her loan to her capital to expand her business. She anticipates reinvesting the new profit in her business.

loans.use: To provide working capital

loans.name: Josiane

texts.en: Josiane is 28 years old and married, with one child who is 10 months old. Josiane sells fruit, which she has done for eight years. Her husband is a businessman. Josiane will use the loan to buy more pineapples, eggplant and yellow bananas to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Josiane plans to buy a plot of land for her residence. In the future, Josiane wishes to get two million Rwandan Francs as capital to establish a new business of her own.

loans.use: To buy fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Aba Mansiwa Mary

texts.en:
Aba Mansiwa Mary A. goes to the seashore to buy fish from the fishermen.  She then fries the fish for sale at Dompoase near Elmina, Cape Coast. She has been selling fish for four years now. 

Aba is a single parent who cares for 4 children, and she is responsible for the upkeep of her home.  Her loan will increase the capital she can use to expand her business. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a shop.

loans.use: To provide working capital for her business

loans.name: Alphonsine

texts.en: Alphonsine is 37 years old and has one child who is 18 years old. She owns a shop selling sugar, rice, milk and a variety of flours. She has done this business for 8 years and it's going well. Alphonsine wishes to reinvest in her business by buying more flour, milk and rice. She plans to add the profits she hopes to make to her savings to buy a refrigerator, because she wishes to sell soft drinks in addition to the other items she sells.

loans.use: To buy more flour, milk and rice

loans.name: Olivier

texts.en: Olivier works as a motorcycle taxi driver. He is 25 years old and single. He has been working as a moto driver for four years. His loan will be used to buy another motorcycle for transportation purpose. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to build a house. His dream is to set up a strong transportation agency and to have a truck in the future.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Ama Nyame Agnes

texts.en: Ama Nyame Agnes E. prepares gari for sale in Dompoase near Elmina, Cape Coast. She is married and has six children. Her husband is a farmer. She helps her husband educate, feed and clothe the children. Ama has been in gari production for 9 years. Her loan will be used to buy fresh cassava to process for sale. Her business objective is to build a storehouse for the gari. To prepare gari, she gets raw fresh cassavas from the market. She washes and peels the cassavas and then sends it to the mill to be milled into dough. She puts the dough in a sack and places heavy stones on it. The stones are placed to drain the starch out of the dough. She leaves the dough for a day or two depending on the weight of the stones. After this process, she stir fries the gari in a pan on a fire (she is stir frying the gari in the photo). The gari is then left to cool and bagged in small bags for sale.

loans.use: To buy fresh cassava to process for sale

loans.name: Clemence

texts.en: Clemence is 30 years old, married, and has four children. Currently, two of her children attend school. Clemence sells different items in her boutique such as rice, sugar, flour, tomatoes and eggs, which she has done for one and half years. Her husband helps her run the business. Clemence will use the loan to purchase more items for her boutique. With the new profits from her expanded business, Clemence plans to install electricity and water in her house.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory such as sugar and different kinds of flour

loans.name: Marie Gloriose

texts.en: Gloriose is 28 years old, married, and has two children. One of her children attends school. Gloriose sells clothes, which she has done for eight years. Her husband is a businessman. Gloriose will use this loan to purchase more clothes and increase the quantity of what she has been selling.  With the new profits from her expanded business, Gloriose wishes to buy a house. She dreams to have a house which will be used as a source of income through renting that house in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes

loans.name: Esi  Nstin Helena

texts.en: Esi Nstin Helena O. is married and has 16 dependents. Esi sells fruits and maize at Dompoase near Elmina, Cape Coast. She has been in this trade for twenty years. Her husband is a farmer. Esi uses her income to pay bills as a way of assisting her husband. Esi is requesting to use the loan to buy more bags of maize to sell and distribute to her growing clientele. She plans to reinvest her new profit.

loans.use: To buy grains to sell

loans.name: Efua Ano Cudjoe

texts.en: Efua Ano Cudjoe S. is single and has 4 children. Efua bakes bread for sale at Dompoase near Elmina, Cape Coast. Efua uses her income to see to the well-being of her home. Efua will use the loan to purchase more flour and other ingredients to bake for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Efua plans to open a snack bar where she can bake other things to sell.

loans.use: To purchase flour and ingredients

loans.name: Abena Nimoe Appiah

texts.en: Abena Nimoe Appiah D. is married and has 2 children. She has been through senior high school. Abena Nimoe sells materials, travelling bags, bathroom slipppers and other items at Dompoase near Elmina in Cape Coast. She has been a trader of these products for 6 years. Her husband is a farmer. Abena uses her income to assist her husband educate their children. Abena will invest the loan in her business by buying more goods to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Abena plans to build another shop.

loans.use: To buy goods to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth Ampong

texts.en:
Elizabeth Ampong E. sells salted dried fish, onions, ripe plantain and other items as a peddler in Dompoase near Elmina in Cape Coast. She is single and takes care of 4 children. She has attained a senior high school level of education. 

From the proceeds of her business, Elizabeth provides her family with basic needs. She is asking for a loan to invest into her business. With the new profits from her expanded business, Elizabeth plans to reinvest it back into her business. 

In this picture Elizabeth is cutting the dried salted fish into pieces to be sold.

loans.use: To invest in food vending business

loans.name: Mahir

texts.en:
Mahir I. is a 40-year-old man living with his wife and children in Sabirabad, the city where he was born. Mahir has a 13-year-old son named Khidayat and an 11-year-old daughter named Sevda. Mahir is a loving father and dreams of giving a good education to his children. 

When he got married 15 years ago, Mahir decided to start a trading business. He now has a vegetable and fruit stand in the local bazaar, but he dreams of opening his own store.  Currrently,  he needs to buy more products to increase his profit. 

Mahir requested a loan in amount of 1800 AZN from AqroInvest and Kiva. This is his first loan. He used this loan to increase his turnover capital and purchase assorted merchandise. Mahir hopes that the extra income from this loan will help improve his business and will allow him to open his own store soon.

loans.use: To purchase assorted merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy equipment to repair cars

loans.name: Jihad

texts.en:
Jihad is a 35-year-old married man living in Bibt Jbeil with his wife and two children. Jihad has been working in transportation for 20 years.  He transports general construction materials. He used to drive others' trucks but seven years ago he bought his own and everything had changed since that time.  His income became better and he became more ambitious about buying another truck in the future.

Jihad is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to buy new wheels for his truck. Most of his clients are construction builders and neighbors who may need him to transport furniture or other heavy things.

loans.use: To buy new wheels for his six-wheel truck

loans.name: Mehman

texts.en:
Mehman H. is 44 years old.  He is married and lives with his wife and three children, aged 19, 17, and 15. He has always been a responsible father who works hard to provide his family a secure and happy life. 

Mehman owns and operates a store, selling a variety of different home products in Sabirabad. He has ten years of experience selling household goods.  Currently, he earns approximately 400 AZN a month from his trading business. 

Mehman received a loan in amount of 1600 AZN from AqroInvest and Kiva. This is his first loan, which was used to buy new goods for his store. After Mehman repays this loan, he plans to apply for more loans to grow his business and enlarge his store.

loans.use: To buy new goods for store

loans.name: Nabil

texts.en:
Nabil is a 40-year-old father of two children who hopefully will see his third child very soon.  He lives happily in Bint Jbeil and is loved by most of its citizens.  Nabil has owned a restaurant since 1994, and has 20 years of experience in this field.  His customers say that his products are tasty and healthy and recommend it to most of their friends and relatives.

Nabil is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to buy necessary materials for his business, and to pay for his wife's childbirth expenses. Nabil is anxiously waiting to see his new baby, and hopes to provide his family with a secure life.

loans.use: To buy materials for restaurant, and pay for delivery of new baby

loans.name: Azada

texts.en:
Azada B. is a 46-year-old woman from Sabirabad, Azerbaijan.  Azada is educated as a pharmacist and is a very diligent woman.  Her husband is a farmer, but his income was not enough to cover all the needs of their five-person family.  In 2002, Azada decided to help her husband earn money for their family. Their primary dream is for their three sons to be able to study and complete a university degree.  

Azada has nine years of experience selling medicine, herbs and medicinal preparations. She requested a loan of 1300 AZN for the first time from AqroInvest and Kiva. With this loan, she bought medicine items in large quantity to expand her business. The extra income from this loan enabled her to pay school fees for her children. Azada is happy and grateful to all.

loans.use: To buy medicine items

loans.name: Ekua Essoun Kakraba

texts.en:
Ekua Essoun Kakraba H. is divorced and has 6 dependents. Ekua sells maize and cooking oil at Dompoase near Elmina in Cape Coast. Ekua uses her income for her dependents’ upkeep. Ekua says the loan is going to serve as additional income to expand her business. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ekua plans to build a shop.

In this picture Ekua is showing a small portion of the maize she sells. The jug is used to store her oil for sale.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama A. is married and has 6 dependents. She has been through senior high school. Ama sells food items such as dried salted fish, spices and other products at Dompoase near Elmina, Cape Coast. She has been in this business for 7 years. Her husband is a farmer. Ama uses her income to assist her husband in paying school fees and utility bills. 

Ama will use the loan to purchase extra food items and items requested by her customers.  She plans to reinvest her new profits.

Ama is holding in her hand the salted dried fish.

loans.use: To purchase food items to sell

loans.name: Adjoa Sakyiwa Abedu

texts.en:
Adjoa Sakyiwa Abedu F. is a single parent taking care of 3 children. She has been through senior high school. Adjoa operates a food stall at Dompoase near Elmina, Cape Coast.  She cooks a variety of food for sale, such as fufu, banku, boiled yam and other dishes. 

Adjoa sees to the well-being of her family with the income generated from her business. She will use the loan to purchase more food items to cook for sale. Her business objective is to build a proper restaurant. 

In this picture, Adjoa is dishing out some of the cooked palmnut soups used to serve on the food.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients to cook food to sell

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua O. is a widow taking care of 7 dependents. She has attained senior high school level of education. Ekua cooks beans and serves it with fried plantain (usually called red-red) at Dompoase near Elmina, Cape Coast. Ekua uses her income to see to the well-being of her family. 

Ekua will use the loan to purchase more sacks of beans and other products to cook for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ekua plans to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients to cook food for sale

loans.name: Ekua Abiba Grace

texts.en:
Ekua Abiba Grace A. is single and has 4 children. She has received a senior high school education. Ekua Abiba sells smoked fish, kokonte (dried cassava that has been processed into powder) and other items at Dompoase near Elmina in Cape Coast.  Cooked kokonte looks like banku, but the colour is slightly different due to the drying of the cassava – it can sometime be dark or brownish in colour.

Ekua takes care of her family with the income she makes from her sales.  She is requesting a loan to add to her initial capital to expand her business. She anticipates reinvesting the new profit back into her business.

In this picture, Ekua is pounding the dried cassava to be milled into powder for sale.

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice A. is divorced and has 7 dependents. She cooks waakye for sale at Dompoase near Elmina, Cape Coast.  Waakye is rice cooked with beans, usually accompanied by fish, macaroni, wele (cow skin), salad and pepper or a tomato-based sauce. 

Beatrice has been in this business for the past eight years. Her income provides food and money for school fees for her dependents. Beatrice will use the loan to purchase additional food items to cook to generate more sales. Her goal is to eventually build a shop.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients to cook for sale

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en:
Adjoa M. is married to a farmer.  They have five children. For five years now, Adjoa has been selling fish and kenkey (a Ghanaian staple, painstakingly made from fermented maize and cassava). Her income is used to pay for their five children’s school fees and for household expenses. 

Adjoa aspires to expand her business and needs the loan to purchase greater quantities of ingredients to produce more food for sale. She aims to reinvest the profits back into her business.

loans.use: To buy ingredients to make food for sale

loans.name: Araba

texts.en: Araba A. is divorced and is the sole breadwinner for 7 children.  She sells kako (dried salted fish) in Dompoase near Elmina, Cape Coast.  She has been in this business for 10 years and her earnings are used to support her family. Her goal is to expand her business to increase her earnings. She requires a loan to buy more fish for sale and also to add to the variety of food she sells.

loans.use: To buy fish and other food to sell

loans.name: Ekua Abokuma Theresa

texts.en:
Ekua Abokuma Theresa M. sells shea butter, beauty products and other items in Dompoase near Elmina, Cape Coast. She has been in this trade for nine years. 

Ekua has completed her senior high school education. She is married to a farmer and they have 5 children. Her earnings are used for their children’s school fees and household expenses. 

To improve her earnings, Ekua requires a loan to add quantity and variety to the products she sells. She will reinvest the profits to expand her business.

loans.use: To add quantity and variety to product line

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena K. has been selling corn and cassava dough at Dompoase near Elmina, Cape Coast, for three years now. She is married and has four children. Her husband is a farmer. Her income from the sale of corn and cassava dough pays for their children’s school fees and their utility bills. She wishes to improve her earnings by purchasing larger quantities of maize and cassava to generate higher sales. Her profits will be reinvested to grow her business further. 

In this picture, Abena is showing the maize she uses for the corn dough.

loans.use: To buy larger quantities of maize and cassava.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua A. sells kenkey, a staple made from fermented corn dough usually served with a spicy sauce and fish, in Dompoase near Elmina, Cape Coast. She has been in this business for two decades. Married to a farmer, she has six children who depend on her income for their school fees. The money she earns also pays for the household’s utilities. Her goal is to use her loan to increase the amount of food she can sell. The increased earnings will be reinvested into her business for further growth.

loans.use: To increase the amount of food she can sell.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua A. is a widow from Dompoase near Elmina, Cape Coast. She has four children. For the past 10 years, she has been selling soap as a way to support her family. She wishes to expand her business with her loan. The money will be used to purchase more soap for sale and also to diversify her product range. Her added earnings will be reinvested in her business for further growth in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more soap

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba M. is divorced and has six children. For the past seven years, Aba has been preparing and selling gari (a major staple in Ghana made from grated cassava) in Dompoase near Elmina, Cape Coast. Her income is used to support her six children and pay for their school fees 
Aba’s focused on growing her business to improve her earnings. She will use the loan to purchase more cassava to prepare more gari for sale. 
In this picture, Aba is in the process of stir-frying the gari.

loans.use: To purchase more cassava to prepare more gari for sale.

loans.name: Nazih

texts.en: Nazih is a 40-year-old married man living in Bint Jbeil with his wife and three kids. Nazih has worked laying house tiles for 12 years. Nazih is a hard worker. He does so in order to provide secure living for his family members. Nazih is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to buy a new machine used to polish the tiles he lays on the floor. His clients like his work a lot and recommend him to most of their neighbors, relatives and friends. Working hard is his way to provide the best education for his kids. He hopes to expand his business to keep a good base for his family members.

loans.use: To buy a machine that polishes tiles

loans.name: Rayan

texts.en: Rayan is a 28-year-old married man and father of three kids who has lived in Bint Jbeil since he was born. Rayan has worked in agriculture for 10 years, which is his only source of income. That's why he works hard on improving his business - to get back the best he can get. Just like many of those his age, Rayan hopes and dreams of a better future, providing secure living to his family members and the best education to his kids. Rayan requests a loan from Al Majmoua to pay the amount left from the new tractor's price, which he bought to increase his income. It's a new agricultural tractor, which helps in doing the requested work faster than before.

loans.use: To pay for his tractor

loans.name: Bilal

texts.en: Bilal is a 38-year-old married man living in Bint Jbeil with his wife and four kids. Bilal has worked in construction for 25 years. He is an expert in his domain, as most of his neighbors and those who deal with him claim. In order to improve his business and to benefit from the construction revolution in the region, Bilal is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua to buy more wood and iron pillars that are necessary in any construction field.

loans.use: To buy wood and iron pillars

loans.name: Grover

texts.es:
Es un señor trabajador, cuenta con una familia reducida, sus hijos se encuentran estudiando en el colegio, el Sr Grover O. tiene una peluquería con mucho sacrificio ya que  ha sufrido mucho en su vida, pero el pudo sobrellevar sus problemas y la situación en que se encuentra.
 
Actualmente hizo cursos de nivelación en un  institutito y quiere  seguir  superándose , el  paso por y nos solicito un crédito para capital de trabajo, donde fue aceptado ya que por  referencia de sus vecinos siempre ha sido una persona responsable y trabajadora.
texts.en:
This is a very hard-working man. He has a small family and his children are in school. Mr. Grover O. has a beauty salon which he has obtained through great sacrifice, since he has suffered greatly in his life. However, he has been able to endure his problems and his situation.

He has just finished courses in an institute and he wants to continue bettering himself. He came to us and requested a loan for working capital, and he was accepted because, according to his neighbours' reference, he has always been a responsible and hard-working person.

loans.use: working capital for his hair salon

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein is a 25-year-old married man and father of two kids who lives Bint Jbeil. Hussein works in construction, especially in cement work. Just like most of the constructors in his region, he works hard to get above the competition. That's why he is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to buy new iron pillars and renew those he has. Hussein hopes to do the best for his family and that will be done only if he works hard to achieve the best. This is his second loan from Al Majmoua. His previous loan was helpful and he was a client in good standing.

loans.use: To buy iron pillars necessary for his business

loans.name: Khalil

texts.en:
Khalil is a 48-year-old married man living in Bint Jbeil with his wife and three children. Khalil sells car accessories and spare parts.  He is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to increase his capital.  

Khalil has a great family to take care of, that's why he works hard to improve his business in different ways. Khalil tries his best always and believes he can improve his business more in the future.

loans.use: To increase his capital

loans.name: Mrs. Srey Phally Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan group consists of seventeen people in Thkov village in Takeo province. Mrs. S. P. is the group's president, selected by the other members who will use their individual portions of the loan for different purposes to improve their families' living standards. Mrs. S. P. is a farmer who owns a two-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family; her husband, Mr. Trok On, is a teacher in a local village where he makes a small salary to contribute. Although they work hard, they can only make a small income. So Mrs. S. P. is seeking for a loan to buy some piglets, pig food, and to build a pigsty to breed pigs. She is the mother of three children all of whom attend the local public school.

loans.use: To buy some piglets, pig food, and build a pigsty too breed pigs

loans.name: Ralph

texts.en:
Ralph D. is from the village of Tagdo, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. He is 28 years old. Ralph is single. To make a living, Ralph owns & operates a  motorela or habal-habal business, providing service to local community members. Ralph has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Ralph joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ralph has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to expand his services. 

Ralph is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tools needed to maintain his vehicle. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Ralph from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the service

loans.name: Zyndel Marie

texts.en:
Zyndel Marie is a 21-year-old single woman who supports her family by operating a sari-sari (general) store. She lives in Puerto Princesa City,  Palawan. 

Zyndel Marie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2010 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 2 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Zyndel Marie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting her family's standard of living.  This time, for her 3rd loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, which she intends to use to buy more stocks for the store so that she can continue to save up for future improvements of her business.

 Zyndel Marie is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stocks to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Bou Naom Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. B. N., born in 1985, is a village group bank loA. president, selected by its twelve members. They will use their individual portions of the loA. in various ways to support their families in Thkov village, Takeo province. Mrs. B. N. is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land where she cultivates rice to sell to support her family; her husband, Mr. Pheap BA., is a vice village chief and construction worker who also earns some money to help. She wants to breed cows, but her saved money is not enough so Mrs. B. N. is applying for a loA. to buy a cow to start her breeding business. This couple has a three-year-old child.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en:
Loreta B. is from the village of Liong, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 29 years old. Loreta is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Loreta owns & operates a business buying and selling seafood products such as sardines & milk fish in the local community. Loreta has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Loreta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Loreta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & fund working capital.  

Loreta is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fish like sardines & salmon to sell. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Loreta from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.
