loans.name: Hin

texts.en: Mrs. Hin K., born in 1943, is a villager in Tonle village in Takeo province. She is a basket maker and a farmer who owns a two-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family. She is a widow who lives with a child and four grandchildren. She wants to start a new cattle-breeding business, but her saved money is not enough so Mrs. Hin K. is seeking for a loan to buy two cows to start her business.

loans.use: To buy two cows

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita T. is from the village of Letican, Mahinog, in Camiguin Province. She is 45 years old. Nenita is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Nenita owns & operates a business buying and selling seafood products such as sardines, shrimps & squids in the local community. Nenita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Nenita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nenita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & fund working capital. 

Nenita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish like salmon & sardines to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Nenita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her  business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fish to sell

loans.name: Vay

texts.en: Mrs. Vay T., born in 1949, lives in Tonle village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Cha Horng, are farmers who own a 4-hectare plot of land where they grow rice to sell to support their family. They also cut palm tree leaves used in roof making to earn extra money. It is time for planting rice so Mrs. Vay T. is applying for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer, and plow her rice field. The couple has three children; one is employed in a garment factory, and the others help their parents.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer, and plow her rice field

loans.name: Mitze Marie

texts.en:
Mrs. Mitze Marie A. is from the village of Tabid, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 36 years old. Mitze Marie is married and has one school-age child. To make a living, Mitze Marie owns and operates a piggery and a farm for coco production. Mitze Marie has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In February 2011, Mitze Marie joined PMPC under Barangay Official Livelihood Assistance (BOLA) program to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mitze Marie is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers for her coco farm and feeds for her piggery. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions for her family, especially in meeting their basic needs, saving for future use, repaying loans, and educating her child.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for coco farm and feeds for piggery

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mrs. Mao K., married to Mr. Chang Chuon, lives in Tonle village, Takeo province. She and her husband are farmers who own a 1.5-hectare plot of land where they grow rice to sell to support their family; they also cut palm tree leaves used in roof making to earn some extra money. Mrs. Mao K. is applying for a loan to buy a new motorbike for her family's transportation needs. She is the mother of a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Paok

texts.en:
Mrs. Paok S. is a farmer who owns a 3 hectare plot of land. She cultivates rice to sell to support her family. She was born in 1970 and she is the mother of four children: two of them are employed in garment factories and the others are studying in a local public school. They live in Tonle village in Takeo province.

Mrs. S.'s husband, Mr. Det Yun, is a traditional musician and a traditional instrument maker who is able to earn some money to support the family. At present, Mrs.  S. has a problem because her husband’s workplace is far away from home. She is seeking a loan to buy a new motorbike.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Ros

texts.en:
Ros V. is a 43-year-old woman who lives in the province of Kompong Tom. To earn a living, Ros V. sells bananas to people who need to buy in bulk as well as retail in the Phsar Lear market. Usually, she can earn a profit of $4.70 per day to support her family. 

Ros Vana was married, but has been divorced from her husband for a few years.  She now lives with her child. In order to make more income, Ros V. is requesting a loan to buy bananas in bulk to stock up for future sales.

loans.use: To buy bananas in bulk

loans.name: Abel

texts.en:
Abel C. is from the village of Comon, Mambajao, in Camiguin Province. He is 30 years old and is single. To make a living, Abel owns and operates a business making and selling snacks and other delicacies like fish ball, tempura, peanuts, flour-coated eggs (or kwik-kwik), juices and beverages in the local community. Abel has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Abel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Abel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional ingredients and fund working capital. 

Abel is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale, like eggs and flour. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Abel from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for make food for sale

loans.name: Virgincita

texts.en:
Virgincita N. is from the village of Liong, Guinsiliban, in Camiguin Province. She is 52 years old. Virgincita is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Virgincita owns & operates a business selling cosmetics and beauty products from NATASHA and AVON in the local community. Virgincita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2011, Virgincita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virgincita is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and fund working capital. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Virgincita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Pak

texts.en: Mrs. Pak K. lives in Tonle village in Takeo province. She was born in 1956 and is a widow with three children, all of whom are employed in garment factories. She is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family. She also cuts leaves of palm trees to make roofs for sale to earn some money. Now she wants to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business, but her saved money is not enough to buy the cow. To address this situation, Mrs. Pak K. is asking for a loan to buy a cow.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Math

texts.en:
Mrs. Math is 60 years old and the mother of six children.  She lives with her family in Phnom Penh City in Cambodia. Currently, she stays at home to care for her children and to cook for her family. Mrs. Math depends on the income from her husband’s fishing and from her four employed children, who are working in different jobs. 

Recently, Mrs. Math's husband cannot catch fish because he lacks the necessary equipment and some of his existing equipment is ruined. Mrs. Math is seeking a loan to allow her husband to repair his broken equipment.

loans.use: To repair broken fishing equipment

loans.name: Roeung

texts.en: Mrs. Roeung N. is a villager in Tonle village, Takeo province. She was born in 1962. She is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family. Mrs. Roeung N. is a mother of five children. One child is a motorbike middleman and another is a government worker. The others are attending in local public school. Mrs. Roeung N.'s husband, Mr. Hak Hoem, is a vice village chief and a palm juice collector who can earn some money to support his family. Recently, Mrs. Roeung N. has had a problem because her family does not have a motorbike for transportation. To improve this condition, Mrs. Roeung N. is requesting a loan to buy a new motorbike.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Miguela

texts.en:
Miguela D. is from the village of Liong, Guinsiliban, in Camiguin Province. She is 42 years old. Miguela is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Miguela operates a business selling seafood products such as sardines & salmon in the local community. Miguela has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2011, Miguela joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Miguela is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish, like salmon & sardines. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Miguela from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy fish to sell

loans.name: Lordita

texts.en:
Lordita is a married woman who lives in Compostela, Cebu. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures:  a fruits & vegetables business and a charcoal & wood business.  Her husband Jeoffrey, who is 37 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living.  They have four children who are between 1 and 6 years old. 

Lordita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 8 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Lordita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 13,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 9th loan, Lorida is borrowing PHP 16,000, which she intends to use to buy more stocks of fruits to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Lordita is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita C. is from the village of Lawigan, Catarman, in Camiguin Province. She is 59 years old. Anita is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Anita owns & operates a business buying and raising pigs for sale. Anita has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Anita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. 

Anita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Anita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Net

texts.en:
Mrs. Net N. is a farmer who owns a piece of land where she cultivates rice to sell to support her family. Mrs. Net N. and her family are living in Saen Ban village in Takeo province. Her husband, Mr. Phoeun Khun, is a coconut seller. He also cuts leave of palm trees to make roofs for sale to earn some money. They support three children, two of whom are enrolled in local public school. The youngest child is a 4-year-old. 

Although they try to work a lot, Mrs. Net N. can earn only a small income. To improve this situation, Mrs. Net N. is borrowing some money from AMK to buy a cow. Her husband is shown in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Sos

texts.en:
Sos S. has been a farmer for a long time. She lives in the Phnom Penh city. She cultivates rice crops on her farmland to earn income. Her husband helps her in the farming business. 

Sos S. has six children, most of them are employed in a variety jobs, and they often share their profit with her to help her with family expenses.  Sos S. would like to request a loan to buy a used motorcycle for her children, who must always hire motor taxis to travel to their job locations.

loans.use: To purchase motorcycle

loans.name: Edes

texts.en:
Edes E. is from the village of Liong, Guinsiliban, in Camiguin Province. She is 40 years old. Edes is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Edes owns & operates a business manufacturing & selling specialty products such as aranyas (fishing nets with nylons & hooks) to local businesses and community members. Edes has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2011, Edes joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edes is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Edes from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Um's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Um B. is a noodle seller in her village and earns some profit to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Korn Koev, is a farmer who owns a 2 hectare plot of land where he grows rice to sell to support his family. She is the mother of three children: two of them are employed in a garment factory and the other one is a construction worker. 

Currently, Mrs. Um B. has a problem because she does not have a kitchen. She is seeking a loan to build a kitchen and will use the rest of the loan to buy rice for the family. 

This group consists of four members from Chreae village in TaK. province. Mrs. Um B. is the group leader who has been selected by the other members. Each will use their portion of the loan in various ways to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To build a kitchen

loans.name: Em's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Em T. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to grow vegetables to support her family. Since her business is getting on well, she wants to expand. To improve production, Mrs. Em T. is seeking a loan to buy vegetable seed and fertilizer. Her husband, Mr. Koeun Port, is a traditional healer who also earns some money to support the family. Through their activity, they support two children who are studying in a local public school.

Four people make up this group from Veay Chhneah village, Takeo province. Mrs. Em T. is the group leader who has been selected by the other members. They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy vegetable seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Michelle May

texts.en:
Michelle May V. is from the village of Bayombong in Nueva Vizcaya. She is 26 years old. Michelle May is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Michelle May owns & operates a business selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Michelle May has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2011, Michelle May joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Michelle May is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Michelle May from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions for family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Lan's Group

texts.en:
Lan A. T. N. is 29 years old. She lives with her family in D. Trung village. Being a  farmer, she focuses on growing rice and potatoes, and raising pigs for meat. Her pig raising activities creates a  stable income every quarter. Since joining our credit program in 2004, Lan A. has always been a good group leader.  Lan A. needs a loan of 5,014,000 VND to buy more pig feed.

P. T. N. is 35 years old. She is raising 200 chickens for eggs. She needs a  loan of 6,322,000 VND to buy chicken feed.

Hang T. N. is 44 years old. She has a business providing lunch for workers at an automobile parts factory. She needs a loan of 6,322,000 VND to buy  more equipment to improve her business.

Hau T. D. is 47 years old.  She runs a workshop that make wood  tables and desks. She needs a loan of 6,322,000 VND to buy materials.

P. T. N. is 35 years old. She is raising 200 chickens for meat. She needs a loans of 5,014,000 VND to buy chicken feed.

loans.use: To buy feed for livestock.

loans.name: Yuon's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Yuon S. is a group loan leader. She has been selected by four members, all of whom make up a group loan in order that each member's portion of the loan can improve their family's standard of living in Prey Chheu Teal village, Takeo province. She is a farmer and owns a half-hectare plot of land, where she grows rice (not to sell, but rather, to support her family), and she is also a weaver. Since her business is getting on well, she wants to expand. So to improve on this purpose, Mrs. Yuon S. is asking for a loan to buy more silk for weaving. She is a widow with a child who is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more silk for weaving

loans.name: Khat

texts.en:
Khat S. is a 55-year-old married woman. She works very hard as a fish-paste seller.  She sells around the community and typically earns around $3.75 per day. Khat S. has another financial earner in her husband, who is a local farmer.  This couple have seven children, two of whom are sewing workers in the garment industry. 

Khat S. wants to earn more income from her selling in order to support the increasing family expense. Therefore, Khat S. decided to pursue a loan to purchase fish-paste in bulk to stock up for sales.

loans.use: To purchase fish-paste in bulk

loans.name: Ermelinda

To make a living, Ermelinda operates a family member's agricultural business, planting and harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Ermelinda has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Ermelinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ermelinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. 

Ermelinda is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Ermelinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet S. is from the village of Flores, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 33 years old. Juliet is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business of making and selling frozen food. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately $81 a month for these activities.

Juliet is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 4th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

loans.name: Mrs. Tin Im Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of eight people from Prey Phdau Cheung village, Takeo province. Mrs. Tin I. is a village bank president and has been selected by the other members, who will use their portion of the loan for different purposes so that it can improve their families' standard of living. 

Mrs. Tin I. is a weaver who is able to earn some money from selling silk cloth in order to support her family. Though her business is getting on well, she wants to expand. To this purpose, Mrs. Tin I. is requesting a loan to buy more silk for weaving. Her husband, Mr. Touch Chel, is a farmer who owns a very small piece of land where he cultivates rice (not to sell, but to support his family) and he is also a construction worker. This couple supports two children who are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more silk for weaving

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana is a married woman who lives in Barangay Tan-awan, in Oslob, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  fish vending and pig fattening. Her husband, Francisco, who is 60 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have four children who are between 22 and 27 years old. 

Juliana joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Juliana has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 15,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of about $187, raising the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 13th loan, she is borrowing 15,000 PHP, which she intends to use for additional capital for the fish vending business so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of her business. Juliana is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Johnny

texts.en:
Johnny A. is from the village of Mapang, Rizal. He is 27 years old. Johnny is married and has one infant-aged child. To make a living, he owns and operates a business, selling a variety of snacks and other delicacies in the local community. He has been operating his business for a year, earning an average monthly net income of $100.

In 2009, Johnny joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting his 1st loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to pay for the renewal of his business permit. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from his business to support his family's needs. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For the renewal for his business permit

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita E. is from the village of North Mapang, Rizal. She is 48 years old. Teresita is married and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, she grows assorted crops to sell. She has been engaged in this activity for twenty years and earns an average monthly net income of $63.

In 2006, Teresita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase supplies. 

Teresita is requesting her 5th loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used for house repair. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to support her family's daily needs. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For house repair

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene is 30 years old and married and supports her family by operating a fishing business. She lives in Daan Bantayan, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of $200. 

Arlene is borrowing 11,000 PHP so that she can purchase fishing gear and equipment.  This will be her 5th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 10,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Arlene aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase fishing gear and equipment

loans.name: Mrs. Sichhoeurn Kea Village Bank Group

texts.en: In Angkor village, Takeo Province, live 12 people who make up a village bank loan. Mrs. Sichhoeurn K. is a village bank president who has been selected by the other members. Each member will use his or her portion of the loan to improve the family's standard of living. Mrs. Sichhoeurn K. and her husband, Mr. Thol Morm, are farmers who own a 1.5-hectare plot of land, where they can grow rice to sell in order to support their family. They sell coffee, too. In the rice field, they have a problem because their field is located far from an irrigation system. In order to improve rice production, Mrs. Sichhoeurn K. is requesting a loan to buy gasoline. She has two children, one of whom is enrolled in local public school, while the youngest one is two years old.

loans.use: To buy gasoline

loans.name: Oyunchimeg

texts.en:
Mrs.Oyunchimeg is a 44-year-old divorcee who lives with her two children in Darkhan, the second largest city in Mongolia. In 2006, she divorced her husband and has been left to raise her children on her own. To sustain her family's living, she has started a shoe resale business at the local outdoor market with $360 in her pocket. 

She gained a lot of experience in retail business and she managed to buy a piece of land with a family house on it. In the future she is planning to do a proper renovation and extension to the house. Currently, she lives in a 10-square-meter rented room with her children. Her eldest son studies in University and took a one year leave because he could not pay his annual fee, and, at the moment, he is helping his mother’s business. Her youngest son studies in secondary school. 

Once a month Mrs.Oyunchimeg travels to Ereen, a Chinese border city, to buy shoes from wholesalers and then sells them at the local market. The loan she is requesting will be used to do renovation and extension to the house.

loans.use: To do renovation and extension to her house

loans.name: Monh

texts.en:
From Siem Reap province, Monh T. is 29 years old and has had a fish sale trade since 2000. Monh T. sells fish that she and her husband themselves catch from the river. She also buys fish from other fishermen when she does not have enough fish to serve her valued clients. By doing this, they are able to generate about $6 per day to solve their daily financial problems. The couple was married many years ago and has been blessed with two children, both of whom are going to school. 

Currently, the quantity of fish caught is decreasing due to the fact that her old boat was broken during the fishing process, and she is lacking fishing tools and supplies. Because of this, Monh T. has requested a loan in order to purchase a new boat and more equipment for her fishing activities.

loans.use: To purchase a new boat, and more equipment for fishing activities.

loans.name: Anelyn

texts.en:
Anelyn M. is from the Barangay of Labo, Ozamiz City, M. Occidental. She is 33 years old. Anelyn is married and has two school-age and two infant children. To make a living she has been working at her business for almost six years and earns approximately $345 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Anelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation. She is requesting an additional loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital for her business. This will be her 7th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her work to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her buy and sell accessories business

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en:
Olivia M. is from the village of Flores, Naguilian, Isabela. She is 40 years old. Olivia is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $75 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Olivia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Olivia is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 3rd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Yel's Group

texts.en: This group loan consists of five people from Ta Su village in Takeo province. Mr. Yel K. is a group leader who has been selected by the other members, each of whom will use a portion of the loan for different purposes in order to improve the standard of living for their families. Mr. Yel K. and his wife, Mrs. Sophun Koev, sell rice, bread, and ice at the school where they can earn some profit to support their family's way of life. In the present, he wants to start a new business, but he does not have enough money to support that goal. To this purpose, Mr. Yel K. is seeking a loan to buy a sugar cane juice machine. He is a father of three children, one of whom is employed in garment factory, one of whom is a student, and the youngest is three years old.

loans.use: To buy a sugar cane juice machine

loans.name: Thuyet

texts.en:
Thuyet T. T. was born in 1957. She lives in Ha Lam village with two sons. She not only grows rice, but also she raises chickens (about 50). Her husband is a construction worker. They have a monthly income of about $209. 

Mrs Thuyet has participated in SEDA since 2004 and has repaid punctually. Last cycle, she borrowed 5,152,000 VND. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 7,194,000 VND to buy food for her chickens.

010116070036-4768

loans.name: Mrs. Neang Chanthol Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of fourteen people from the village of Chumrov, in Takeo province. Mrs. Neang C. is the village bank president who has been selected by the other members. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her famiL.. She is also a weaver. Since her weaving business is going well, she wants to expand. So Mrs. Neang C. is applying for a loan to buy more silk for weaving.

loans.use: To buy more silk for weaving

loans.name: Leticia Henriette

texts.en:
Leticia Henriette P. is from Barangay Vista Hill, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 54 years old. Leticia Henriette is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Leticia Henriette has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately $138 a month for these activities.

Leticia Henriette is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her 2nd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Con

texts.en: Con T. N., who was born in 1950, lives in Ha Lam village and is the mother of three children.  Her husband is a worker in the company near her house, while Con grows rice and raises chickens. Now raising over 200 chickens, she has a monthly income of about 3.000.000 (VND). She has participated in SEDA since 2004 and has always repaid her loans punctually. Con is now requesting a loan of 9.810.000 VND to invest in her livestock.

loans.use: To invest in her livestock.

loans.name: Prum

texts.en: Mrs. Prum Y. is a widow with two children, one of whom is a driver who earns a low salary, while the other is a farmer. She and her family live in the village of Dei Chrab, in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she grows rice to sell to support her family. Although she tries to work hard, she can earn only a small income. So to improve this condition, Mrs. Prum Y. is seeking a loan to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Que

texts.en:
Que T. N., a resident of Ha Lam village, was born in 1967, is married to a carpenter, and has two sons. Que is a farmer, breeding pigs and poultry, and is currently raising six pigs. The family has a monthly income of about 5.000.000 VND. Que has participated in SEDA since 2004 and has always repaid her loans punctually. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 6.322.000 VND to breed more pigs.

Always working hard to save money, Que wants to have a workshop in the future.

loans.use: To breed  pigs.

loans.name: Toch

texts.en:
Toch T., 62, lives in the Province of Kompong Tom in Cambodia, where she earns her living raising pigs. She has run this business since 1990, and it has provided her with income to attain her standard of living. Toch T., a widow, lives with her two children, one a clothes seller and the other a fresh fish seller.

Recently Toch T.’s daughter sold nearly all of her inventory to her buyers and now wants to replenish her stock but lacks the necessary capital. To assist her daughter, Toch T. is asking for a Kiva loan to help her daughter acquire more clothes to resell.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to resell.

loans.name: Thanh

texts.en: Thanh T. P. was born in 1954. She has 4 children( two sons and two daughters). She raises ducks and grows rice and right now she  has 400 ducks. Her husband was retired. They have a monhly income of about 5.000.000 VND. She has participated in SEDA since 2004 and repaid her loans punctually. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8.502.000 VND to buy food for her ducks.

loans.use: to buy food for her ducks.

loans.name: Hai

texts.en: Hai T. N. was born in 1969. She lives in Ha Lam 3 village with her husband and two children. Not only does she grow rice but also raises 10 pigs and 300 chickens. Her husband is building worker. They have a monthly income of about 5.000.000 Vietnamdong (VND). She needs this loan to invest in her livestock. She has participated in SEDASo since 2005. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 5.886.000 VND to buy feed for her pigs and chickens.

loans.use: to buy feed for pigs and chickens.

loans.name: Pich

texts.en: Pich B. is 54 years old and a resident of Siem Reap Province. She earns a living by cultivating rice crop as well as raising ducks in a cage behind her house. She raises ducks to produce eggs and sells the eggs to people who come to buy in bulk at her village. She is married with three single children and five married children, and most of them have already started new families. Her husband’s name is Chom Chory who works with her in the business. Pich B. has applied for a $600 loan from Kiva’s partner HKL in order to purchase additional feed and ducklings to raise.

loans.use: To purchase additional feed and ducklings to raise.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda M. is from the village of Flores, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 45 years old. Rosalinda is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Rosalinda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Rosalinda has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP when she sells one of her raised hogs.

In 2009, Rosalinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase young livestock to raise & sell in future. Rosalinda is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Rosalinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Belinda

texts.en:
Belinda D. is from the village of Flores, Naguilian, Isabela. She is 39 years old. Belinda is married and has three school-aged children. 

To make a living, Belinda raises livestock, primarily pigs, for fattening and sale. Belinda has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Belinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Belinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. 

Belinda is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Belinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

texts.en:
Shirley C. is from the village of Bacnor West, Burgos, Isabela. She is 49 years old. Shirley is married and has seven school-aged children. 

To make a living, Shirley owns and operates a general store. Shirley has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Shirley joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Shirley is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Shirley from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

texts.en:
Edna S. is from the village of Bacnor West. She is 24 years old. Edna is married and has one infant child. 

To make a living, Edna prepares and sells cooked food for daily meals. Edna is just starting this business.

In 2011, Edna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Edna is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the first loan taken out by Edna from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and  expand her business. 

About ASKI:

loans.name: Mrs. Oem Tong Village Bank Group

texts.en: Sixteen people who make up a village bank loan live in the village of Doung Khpos, in Takeo province. They will use their portions of the loan for different purposes to improve their families' lives. Mrs. Oem T. is the village bank president who has been selected by the other members. She is a farming laborer who is able to earn some money to support her family. She is a widow with a child who is employed in a garment factory. She can earn only a small income although she works hard. So to improve this condition, Mrs. Oem T. is applying for a loan to buy some piglets and pig food to start a new business breeding pigs.

loans.use: To buy some piglets and pig food for breeding

loans.name: Men

texts.en:
Men S. has been earning a daily income by growing rice in the province of Kompong Tom. She and her husband spend most of their time working in the farm field. This family typically earns an average profit of $5 each day in order to meet their family’s need. They are blessed with four single children, two of whom work in the construction field. 

One of Men S.’s children will marry soon, but she doesn’t have sufficient cash to hold the ceremony. To deal with this situation, Men S. would like to ask for loan to add to her personal savings so that she can prepare the wedding ceremony for her child on time.

loans.use: To prepare the wedding ceremony for her child

loans.name: Kean

texts.en:
Kean N. is a 48-year-old resident of the Kompong Tom province. He makes a living selling firewood that he has chopped from the forest himself and stored in his home to sell. 

Kean N. is married to Im Phorn, age 53, a rice farmer. She is the mother of seven children, five of whom are single and two of whom are married. Two sons are employed as sellers of chopped wood and one daughter works in a garment factory. 

To assist the farming business and alleviate hard physical labor, Kean N. needs to request a loan for his wife to buy one buffalo to use for plowing the farmland.

loans.use: To buy one buffalo to use for plowing the farmland

loans.name: Kosar's Group

texts.en:
Kosar lives in a small city of Punjab, Pakistan, called Kasur. Kasur city is famous for its leather industry.  Kosar owns a 4-room house there and has been living in the area of Faqeerwala with her family for over 5 years.  She is 50 years of age and is married to M. Y., who makes and sells shoes. He deals with different shoe shops in the city and fulfills their orders on time to earn an income for the family. He is very well known in his community and among his clients as a master in his work. 
Kosar supports her family by doing embroidery. She receives orders from her community members and fulfills them on time. She utilizes that money for paying utility bills. 
Kosar has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for the improvement of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will purchase leather, nails, shoe polisher, etc., in larger quantities. This will help him to finish larger orders on time and make better profits.  He has been doing this business for the past 5 years, and Kosar is confident that a loan investment will bring better profits to him and help him to expand his business.  She is a new loan applicant of Asasah. 

Note: "In the photo, the lady with a raised hand is Kosar".

loans.use: To buy leather, nails and shoe polisher for shoe making & selling business

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea R. is a hard-working man who always tries his best to earn money in order to help support the whole family. To earn a living, he often goes to the river near his community catch fresh fish, and he sells firewood also. He can make a profit of approximately $2.80 a day from this business. Chea R.'s  wife is a local farmer. This couple has given birth to six children, five of whom are single.  The other one is married and lives away from home. Chea R. is taking out his first loan to purchase a piece of farmland in a good location for farming, on which he will grow different kinds of crops. In addition, he will rent his land to another farmer for a fee.

loans.use: To purchase a piece of farmland in a good location for farming, on which he will grow different kinds of crops.

loans.name: Mrs. Oem Oeur Village Bank Group

texts.en: In the village of Doung Khpos in Takeo province, twelve people have made up a village bank loan. With a portion of the loan, each member will improve each family's standard of living. Mrs. Oem O. is the village bank president who has been selected by the other members. She is a pig breeder who can earn some profit to support her family while her husband, Mr. Chanthy P., is a cow middleman who can also earn some money to support his family. Since her husband’s business is going well, she wants to expand. So Mrs. Oem O. is applying for a loan to add to her savings to buy a cow for resale. Mrs. Seynoeun Soem and Mrs. Tit Norn are group guarantors, so they are also shown in the picture.

loans.use: To buy a cow for resale

loans.name: Luwsandagva

texts.en:
Luwsandagva is 33 years old and lives with his wife, son, and daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His family lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian felt tent, in his brother's yard. His son is 11 years old and goes to primary school, while his daughter attends kindergarten. His wife, Tugsjargal, works as a petrol server at a local petrol station. Luvsandagva worked as a woodworker at a local timber company from 2002 to 2003.

Luwsandagva supports his family by operating his carpentry business. When he began his business in 2005, he owned his business with his four friends. Their business has grown, and he has begun to operate his business apart from his friends in February, 2011. Now he has about 1 million Mongolian tukrigs (MNT) in wood working equipment and 600,000 MNT in materials. Luwsandagva is an honest person, and hardworking. He is requesting a 1,600,000 MNT loan. He will purchase more wood working equipment.

He wants to grow his business with this loan and eventually have a carpentry factory.  His family wants to buy their own yard and a small house in 2011.

loans.use: To purchase more wood working equipment

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna is a 51-year old married woman who supports her family by operating 2 business ventures: general store and ambulant vending (vegetable) businesses. She lives in Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2010, and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and ambulant vending (vegetable) businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 15000. Myrna is borrowing PHP 12000 so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her third loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 7000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Myrna aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the  Dungganon way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Adyabold

texts.en:
Adyabold is 25 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They all live together in an old, small house. His wife works in a department store as a salesperson. Adyabold operated a taxi service for the past few years by using his friend’s car. During that time, he gained much experience in conducting a business. He is currently employed at a taxi company as a taxi driver. Adyabold is a very hard-working person and is known for his good character. 

His house is too small for his family, and it needs repair. So he is asking for a loan to purchase insulation materials for the house.

loans.use: To purchase insulation materials for his house.

loans.name: Ghulam Khadija

texts.en:
Ghulam Khadija is a 32 year-old lady, residing in a city named Kasur, in Pakistan. Kasur is a small city and known for its tannery industry. She is an educated lady. She got her education up to the 12th standard. She wants to study further but her parents wished for her to be married and settled in her life. She got married to M. Y., who runs a medical store in the market. He has been in this business for the past 11 years. During those years, he has gotten a good reputation among his clients by providing them with quality medicines.  
Ghulam khadija has given birth to three children, two daughters and one son. Her elder daughter is in 5th grade and a son is in first grade. Her younger daughter is just one year old. 
Ghulam Khadija is a very cooperative lady. She operates a school in the community. All the children of her community come to her school to get an education. She earns a good income every month. Now she has become an earning part of the family. Her family respects her alot and loves her for her good and hardworking nature. 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy medicines to sell in his medical store.
She is a new loan user of Asasah and hopes that It will be a profitable experience for her.

loans.use: To buy medicines for selling

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Meas E. is a married woman with two children who go to the local school. She sells a variety of Khmer cakes and desserts in one small kiosk in her village in Kompong Tom province. She has other financial support from her husband, who is a window and bed maker.  This family can earn around $4.6 per day to ensure their family a comfortable life. Recently, her husband ran out of raw materials from his stock supply. This has caused frequent interruptions to his operations. Therefore, Meas E. would like a loan to be used for her husband to buy wood to make beds to sell.

loans.use: To buy wood for her husband to make beds to sell.

loans.name: Erma

texts.en:
Erma G. is from the village of Nagassican, Santiago City. She is 55 years old. Erma is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Erma owns & operates a business venture in the food sector, making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Erma has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Erma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Erma is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Erma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 53 years old, married, and supports her family by fishing. She lives in Daan Bantayan, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has been improving her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable.  She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 11,000. Elizabeth is borrowing PHP 13,000 so that she can purchase paint and a new engine for the fishing boat. This will be her 5th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Elizabeth aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase paint and a new engine for a fishing boat

loans.name: Enrequita

texts.en:
Enrequita is a married woman who lives in Daan bantayan, Cebu. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures: tailoring and a general store.  Her husband, Pablito, who is 49 years old, works as a tailor to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have 5 children who are between 11 to 21 years old. Enrequita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past 5 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Enrequita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 6th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000.  She intends to use it to buy materials for the sewing machine so that she can continue to save up for her children's education and the improvement of her home & store. Enrequita is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase raw materials for the sewing machine

loans.name: Luzviminda's Group

texts.en:
Luzviminda C. is from the village of Faustino, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 43 years old. Luzviminda is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Luzviminda is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Luzviminda owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling vegetables in the local community. Luzviminda has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Luzviminda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luzviminda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Luzviminda is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Luzviminda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita M. is a 42-year-old married woman who supports her family by fishing. She lives in Daan Bantayan, Cebu. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her fishing business, Rosita is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 9,000. 

Rosita is borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she can purchase fishing gear and equipment.  This will be her fifth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. 

Rosita aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon, a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase fishing gear and equipment

loans.name: Sheryl

texts.en:
Sheryl R. is from the village of Bantay Solana, Cagayan. She is 25 years old. Sheryl is married and has two school-aged children. 

To make a living, Sheryl plants and harvests rice for sale. Sheryl has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2009, Sheryl joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Sheryl has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 

Sheryl is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 
This will be the third loan taken out by Sheryl from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana M. is a married woman who lives in Daan Bantayan, Cebu. Her husband, Mario, who is 45 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living. They have three children who are between 18 and 24 years old. 

Susana earns her living by operating a general store
. 
Susana joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past two loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Susana has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 6,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her third loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, with which she intends to buy stocks of goods for the store to sell so that she can continue to save up for future improvements to her house and for the education of her children. 

Susana is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon, a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to sell

loans.name: Apolinario

texts.en:
Apolinario M. is a married man from the village of Bantay. He is 44 years old. 

To make a living, Apolinario plants and harvests rice for sale. Apolinario has been engaged in his business for over 22 years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP every crop season.

In 2011, Apolinario joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his business and living situation. Apolinario is requesting a loan of 22,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the first loan taken out by Apolinario from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.
