loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia Y. is a married woman who lives in Narra, Palawan. 

She earns her living by selling cosmetic products.

Her husband, Oscar, who is 49 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.

They have four children who are between 12 and 24 years old. 

Sylvia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past 20 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Sylvia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. 

Her previous loan of PHP 29,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 21st loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500, with which she intends to buy more stocks of cosmetic products so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. 

Sylvia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon, a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stocks of cosmetics products

loans.name: Mahasa Bee Keepers Group-Kyenjojo

texts.en: T. Wilson is 63 years old, married, and has seven children.  For the past two years, he has been running a general merchandise retail shop in Kawaruju-Kyenjojo. His business generates 30,000 shillings a week. Wilson also runs a small agricultural business. With this loan, he is going to purchase more retail commodities to sell at his shop. He is affiliated with the Mahasa Bee Keepers Group-Kyenjojo.

loans.use: To purchase more retail commodities to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase wooden material

loans.name: Jia's Group

texts.en:
Jia lives with her family in Lahore, which is famous for its history and culture in Pakistan. She lives there in a 2 room brick house. She is 45 years old, and has given birth to 2 sons. Her eldest son works in a private organization while the second one is a motor mechanic. 

Jia supports her family by selling clothes. She purchases clothes from the famous clothes markets of Lahore called “AnarkA.” and “Azam market” and sells to her local area clients. She operates this business from her home and earns a good income every month. Besides her business, she also gives the proper time to her household activities and makes the utmost effort to provide comfort to her family.  

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her clothes selling business. With the loan, she will buy clothes of different variety in bulk quantity. She expects that her business will improve after the loan investment and she will be able to make more sales and profits by offering more varieties of clothes to the clients. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 6th loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meetings.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To fund the operations of hamburger & siopao business.

loans.name: Jane's Group

texts.en:
Jane O. is from the village of Mangandingay Cabarroguis, Quirino. She is 36 years old. Jane is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Jane O.'s group.

Jane is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Jane owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Jane has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 3,200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jane joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jane has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Jane is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Jane from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel is a married woman who lives in Madridejos, Cebu. She earns her living by operating 3 business ventures:  pig fattening, fishing and fish selling businesses. Her husband Pepi, who is 31 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have four children who are 7 months to 12 years old.

Maricel joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 15 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Maricel has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 27,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 35,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 16th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500, which she intends to use to buy feed, medicine and vaccines for the pigs, and repair the fishing boat so that she can continue to save up for future education and expansion of business. Maricel is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase medicine and vaccines for pigs.

loans.name: Armogast

texts.en:
Armogast is a married man with four children, three of whom attend school while one graduated from school. He owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food.

He has operated a fuel selling business for the past one year, selling from home to motorcycle operators. Armogast faces a major challenge of high prices of fuel which reduces the number of clients. He hopes to establish a fuel station for selling fuel. 

With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to purchase fuel for resale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase fuel for resale.

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Sam P. is an old married woman who lives in a small house in Kompong Chhnang province. She is a Khmer noodle seller in her community, and she has been in this business since 1991. She can get a net income from her business of about $4 US per day to support her family's daily expenses. She has a life partner in her husband who is a local farmer. Sam P. has two children; one is single and also sells Khmer noodles, and the other one is married. Both of them work in a variety of occupations to make a regular profit.

Sam P. will be using this Kiva loan to purchase essential ingredients for making Khmer noodles. She proposes to use the rest of the loan to assist her daughter’s business.

loans.use: To purchase essential ingredients for making Khmer noodles, and to use the rest of the loan to assist her daughter’s business.

loans.name: Enhtuvshin

texts.en:
Enhtuvshin, 47, is married and lives with her husband and son in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. Her two older daughters attend college and her younger son attends a local primary school. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, and are building a winter home on their property.

Enhtuvshin began working for a restaurant as a cook in 1991. Her husband drives a truck, which they use for their transportation and trading business. Her husband transports shipments for a company and also brings coal that he sells at the local market in the winter time. Enhtuvshin is a hardworking and active person who says, " My husband and I work hard because we want our children to get a good education. After our daughters graduate from the University we will finish building our winter house". Enhtuvshin is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 MNT to buy spare parts for their truck and cover the maintenance fees.

loans.use: To buy spare parts.

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is a married man with two children, all of whom graduated from school. He owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

He has operated a retail shop business for the past one year, selling to his neighbours and motorcyclists. Richard faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation in his business. He hopes to expand and operate a wholesale shop in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to purchase bundles of maize flour, rice and wheat flour for sale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of maize flour, rice and wheat flour for sale.

loans.name: Zubaydulo

texts.ru: Мирзоев Зубайдуло проживает в городе Душанбе. Ему 45 лет. Он женат, имеет троих детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Он сам имеет средне - специальное образование, товаровед. По специальности проработал два года. Сейчас он занимается торговлей на рынке Сафариён. Арендует торговую точку, где продает овощи. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже три года. Кредит просит для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en: Zubaydulo M. lives in the city of Dushanbe.  He is 45 years old, married and has three children.  His wife is a homemaker.  He has a secondary-specialized education, as a merchandiser.  Zubaydulo worked in that profession for two years.  Currently, he is involved in sales at the Safariyon market.  He leases a retail outlet, where he sells vegetables.  He has been in this business for three years.  He is requesting this loan in order to increase product turnover.

loans.use: Increasing product turnover

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase goats for sale.

loans.name: Keal

texts.en:
From the province of Kompong Tom, Keal C. is a rattan cupboard seller who is 47 and is a married mother caring for four single kids, two of whom are working in a variety of jobs.

Since 2007, Keal C. and her husband have sold her rattan cupboards in front of their house. This couple also orders rattan items in bulk from braiders and then sell them retail door-to-door across the province. They always take a week to sell their products. Keal C. now runs her business very well because she sells her items at a reasonable price. In order to better satisfy the needs of the customers, Keal C. seeks a US$1200 loan to stock a larger amount of rattan cupboards to sell. With the rest of her fund, she will buy a plot of farmland for farming.

loans.use: To stock a bigger amount of rattan cupboards to sell, and to buy a plot of farmland.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna is a 48 year old widow who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  buying and selling spices and cosmetics products businesses. She lives in Narra, Palawan.

Lorna joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Lorna has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 23,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 12,500, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for her businesses so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Lorna is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stocks of spices and cosmetics products.

loans.name: Ailaine

texts.en:
Ailaine B. is from the town of Banga. She is 36 years old. Ailaine is married and has 3 children aged 13, 10 and 4. To make a living, Ailaine owns and operates a business venture in the agricultural sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Ailaine works hard to ensure healthy crops and increased harvests.

Ailaine joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ailaine has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Ailaine is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase sacks of fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition fees. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Thu

texts.en: Thu T. N. is 37 years old with 2 children who are at secondary school. Since her first loan from our Credit program in 2004, she has opened a small grocery shop. Her shop developed year after year, and now it is an agent to support smaller stores. Profit earned from this agent is 4,000,000 VND per month. To expand more, she would like to borrow 9,810,000 VND to buy more goods to meet the increasing demand of customers.

loans.use: To buy more goods to meet the increasing demand of customers.

loans.name: Gurragchaa

texts.en:
Gurragchaa is 30 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They all live together in a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent on his sister’s plot of land. Gurragchaa’s wife is a waitress at café. Two of the couple’s children attend the local secondary school and youngest daughter stays at home. 

For the past three years, Gurragchaa has operated a taxi service in city. During the day, he stays at home looking after his youngest daughter and taking the older children to and from school. In the evening, he starts his taxi service. Gurragchaa is a very hardworking person who is providing income to cover his family expenses as well as giving his children a good education and instilling good morals. 

Gurragchaa is requesting a loan to increase his working capital and to purchase spare parts for his car.

loans.use: to increasing working capital and purchase spare parts

loans.name: Na

texts.en: Na T.  D. is 37 years old with 1 small child, and lives in Kim village. Ms. Na has a shop that sells sugar cane trees. Her business is quite good , especially in summer when the weather becomes hot. She has run this business for 6 years right after she borrowed her first loan, and she said that this micro credit program was convenient for those whose have small businesses. To develop her business more, she wants to have a loan of 8,502,000 VND in this loan cycle.

loans.use: To develop her business more.

loans.name: Huong

texts.en:
Huong T. N. is 31 years old.  Being a farmer, she has focused on growing rice and vegetables, and raising 200 chickens for meat. Agricultural products are used to support her family's food needs, and the sales provide an income for daily expenditures.

Regarding her participation in our credit program, she is a good cluster leader. Currently, she wants to have a loan of 9,810, 000VND to buy food and improve the chicken house.

loans.use: To buy food and improve chicken house.

loans.name: Rani's Group

texts.en:
Rani belongs to a big metropolis called Lahore, the second largest city of Pakistan. She is 40 years old and has lived with her family in a 3 room brick house in the area of Yadgar for the past 26 years. She is married to S. M., who is a blacksmith and makes iron boxes on order. The iron boxes are used to keep clothes, quilts and blankets in houses. He has been doing this business for the past 5 years and has a good number of clients in his area who give him regular orders due to his ability to make quality boxes at cheap rates. 

Rani is a caring lady, who prefers to stay at home and manage the household chores. She has a very good nature and loves keeping flowers at home. She enjoys taking care of them. She is the mother of 2 sons. Her eldest son is a tailor by profession while the second one is studying in class 9. 

Rani has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the improvement of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy iron to make more iron boxes for selling. Rani is hopeful that the loan investment will help her husband to improve his business and also for her family to enjoy a better life. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 4th loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meetings.

This is a group loan. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

loans.use: To buy iron for making iron boxes for selling.

loans.name: Sheila

texts.en:
Sheila is a married woman who lives in Madridejos, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  general store and pig fattening. Her husband Francisco, who is 36 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have two children who are 8 and 10 years old, and currently going to school.

Sheila joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Sheila has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 49,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 17th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 49,500, which she intends to use to buy more stock for the general store so that she can continue to save up for future education and home renovation costs. Sheila is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Sung

texts.en: Sung T. D. is 52 years old. She has been a farmer for a long time, and her main activities are focused on raising cows. She has milk every day to sell, and this activity creates a stable income to cover her family's expenses. She has been our client since 2004, and she has used loans very effectively in expanding her business. Last year, she borrowed 5,886,000 VND to buy grass and baby trees to supply food for the cows. Currently, she wants to have a loan of 6,322,000 VND to improve the shelter for them.

loans.use: To improve cattle shelter.

loans.name: Son

texts.en:
Son V. N. is 37 years old.  He has a grocery shop in Kim market. He has run this kind of business since 2004, and he has quite a stable income to cover his family's expenditures and pay school fees for two children who are at high school and secondary school.

Mr. Son joined in our credit program in 2004 and has always been a good repayer. To buy more goods to meet the demand of customers, he wants  to have a  loan of 9,810,000 VND. He said that this kind of loan is very suitable for his business.

loans.use: To buy more goods to meet the demand of customers.
